did.abstract: Jackson, Michigan physician; medical practice records, correspondence, school materials, personal, and photographs

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: This collection is part of a series of donations made by the Pray family (donor no. 4444).

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Board of Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., George R. Pray Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: George Raymond Pray was born in Ionia June 16, 1878. His father was George W. Pray, one of the eleven members of the University of Michigan's first graduating class in 1845, and he followed in his father's footsteps by enrolling at Michigan in 1896. He was a member of the Phi Beta Pi medical fraternity, and in 1900 he received his medical degree. He worked as an intern at the University Hospital from 1900 to 1902, spending the latter two years as first assistant in gynecology and obstetrics. In 1902 he accepted a position as physician at the Michigan State Prison in Jackson. He married Zoe K. Porter around 1912. He kept a practice from his office at home for many years and retired from medicine in the summer of 1967. He died Christmas Eve, 1967.

scopecontent.p: The George R. Pray collection consists of five series: Medical Practice, Correspondence, School Materials, Personal, and Photographs.

controlaccess.head: Subjects:
controlaccess.subject: Physicians--Michigan--Ann Arbor.
Physicians--Michigan--Jackson.
controlaccess.corpname: University of Michigan. Dept. of Medicine and Surgery.

scopecontent.p: The Medical Practice series (2.0 linear feet) consists of published books, as well as record books created by Pray for his personal use and reference. The published books are primarily medical, used by Pray while in medical school at the close of the nineteenth century. These books, some including handwritten notes and annotations, give insight to medical practice and instruction of the period. Pray's record books, including his financial records, appointment books, and notebooks illustrate his organized nature and attention to detail. Also included in this series are miscellaneous newspapers from the Ann Arbor and the University of Michigan.

did.unittitle: Pharmacology and Therapeutics by S.A. Matthews
Practical Notes on Urinary Analysis by W.B. Canfield
Outlines of Anatomy by William A. Campbell

unittitle.title: Calendar of the University of Michigan for 1896-1897

did.unittitle: Directions for Laboratory Work in Bacteriology by Frederick G. Novy
A List of the Birds and Mammals Collected by the Steere Expedition to the Philippines by J.B. Steere
The Distribution of Genera and Species of Non-Migratory Land Birds in the Philippines by J.B. Steere

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series (0.6 linear feet) includes letters from friends and family received by Pray while in Ionia, Ann Arbor, and at Woodard Lake. Most concern school, health, and life back home. These letters span the years 1879-1899.

did.unittitle: Correspondence regarding diary of George W. Pray, 1924

scopecontent.p: The School Materials series (0.1 linear foot) spans the years 1880-1900 and consists of miscellaneous materials, including notes, grade reports, account transactions, and graduation announcements, primarily from the University of Michigan, but also from elementary school and Ann Arbor High School.

The Personal series (0.1 linear feet) includes miscellaneous items spanning Pray's life, including an obituary from the Foote Memorial Hospital bulletin, list of books read by 1894, dance and party invitations, and rosters from the Jackson Conopus Club.

The Photographs series (0.2 linear feet) consists primarily of portraits, but some snapshots and taxidermy photos are also included. Roughly half of the photo subjects are identified, but few appear to be members of the Pray family itself. The photographs are undated.

did.unittitle: Portraits from Ionia, Owosso, and Ann Arbor
